content: European stocks are on a tear. They’re up 5.5% so far this year, hitting levels not seen since May 2008. U.S. stocks, on the other hand, are little changed. I’m tempted to add to my European stock exposure, given how rich sentiment and valuations are in the U.S., relative to Europe. But is it too late? Not at all, say money managers who are overweight European stocks. “We still like Europe. We think there is a compelling value opportunity there,” NorthRoad Capital Management portfolio manager Raymond Vars told me recently. Chad Deakins, a portfolio manager at the RidgeWorth International Equity Fund STITX, +1.40%  is overweight Europe, especially cyclical companies, the more economically sensitive ones that do better when economies rebound. Of course, Europe appears to face several challenges, from deflation and military conflict in Ukraine, to problems, again, with Greek debt. But that’s what creates the opportunity. Ed Yardeni, an economist and strategist with Yardeni Research, agrees that European bulls are on the right track. “The question is whether the fundamentals are improving enough to boost earnings. Investors seem to think so, and we are coming around to the same opinion,” Yardeni says. To see why, let’s consider six reasons to favor Europe over U.S. stocks, and eight European stocks that look among the best to buy. ‘All the economic indicators are clearly suggesting that a recovery is taking hold once again.’ David Hussey, Manulife Reason 1: European stocks look cheap relative to U.S. stocks. European stocks recently had a forward price-to-earnings ratio (P/E) of 15.1, compared with 17.5 for the U.S., Yardeni points out. But a lot of European companies trade at much steeper discounts to their U.S. equivalents. “This creates an opportunity for value investors,” says Vars, whose NorthRoad International Fund US:NRIEX outperforms competing funds by an annualized 1.2 percentage points over the past five years, according to Morningstar. While operating margins and profits at U.S. companies are at all-time highs, there’s still a lot of room for improvement in these metrics at European companies, Vars says. “In Europe, there is more basic blocking-and-tackling that can take place.” A return of European profit margins to 2007 peaks, which isn’t out of the question, would move stocks up 20% to 30%, says David Hussey, who oversees European investments in the London offices of Manulife Asset Management. To see why that might actually happen, take a look at the following reasons to favor Europe over the U.S. now. Reason 2: Europe just launched quantitative easing. Like the Fed a few years back, the European Central Bank is now launching a massive quantitative-easing (QE) program. Starting this month, it will buy 60 billion euros, or $66.3 billion, worth of government debt a month until well into 2016, to try to boost growth. “As countries embark on QE or free-money programs, equity markets go up. That’s that,” says John Lekas of Leader Capital. “Europe equity markets are going higher across the board.” Reason 3: The weak euro will boost exports. The euro has fallen sharply from its peak last year, and it may have a bit more to go, says Deakins, whose RidgeWorth International Equity Fund outperformed competitors over the past five years. That’s great for European exporters, since their stuff now looks cheaper to foreigners. “A lot of European companies export a significant amount, and, as the euro has fallen, their earnings have grown.” This is going to continue. In contrast, the strong dollar is a headwind for U.S. exporters. Reason 4: Bank’s are lending more, and not just to one another. Over the three months through January, private-sector lending by financial institutions jumped to 612.8 billion euros at an annualized rate, the best pace since October 2008, Yardeni says. Lending to non-financial companies posted its first gain since November 2011, and mortgage lending rose to 114 billion euros, the most since June 2011. Reason 5: Countries are making reforms that help the economy. Ireland, Spain, Portugal, France and Italy have made varying degrees of progress in lifting regulations and easing job-market rules, changes that can lead to better growth, Yardeni says. Ireland and Spain are now the fastest-growing economies in the European Union. Portugal is improving as well. Reason 6: Despite all the gloomy headlines, European economies are perking up. “All the economic indicators are clearly suggesting that a recovery is taking hold once again,” Hussey says. “This time it won’t be snuffed out by an appreciating currency.” A few data points: Retail sales jumped 3.7% in January from a year earlier. That was the best pace since November 2008, Yardeni says. Wages in Germany recently rose 3.2%. Factory orders were up 2.5% in December from November, the fastest rate since June 2011. Business sentiment and the region’s Purchasing Managers Index have also been rebounding. Stocks liked by investment professionals Koninklijke KPN KKPNY, -1.49% is a Dutch telecom company caught up in the sector’s price wars, which have been encouraged by European regulators. Now regulators favor less cutthroat pricing competition and more consolidation, so that European telecom companies can make enough to invest in next generation of broadband networks, Hussey says. This is one reason he likes the earnings and dividend growth prospects at KPN. He also likes U.K.-based Rio Tinto RIO, +2.65% a diversified mining company whose low costs help explain its prodigious cash flow. The company’s low payout ratio suggests there’s room to raise the dividend. It already offers a 5% dividend yield. Vars, at at NorthRoad Capital Management, likes Akzo Nobel AKZOY, -1.20% an Amsterdam paints and coatings company that’s been closing plants, selling off businesses and carrying out other restructuring to bring down costs. Now all it needs is a rebound in demand. That might be in the cards as the economy picks up. Vars also likes the financial sector, which still trades at a healthy discount to peers elsewhere in the world. One favorite: Amsterdam-based ING Groep ING, +0.06% trading at just over 1 time book value. It has been selling insurance divisions to focus on banking. That’s enabled ING to shore up its balance sheet and reinstate its dividend, which Vars expects to grow substantially. Since Germany is such a big exporter, its economy is one of the main beneficiaries of the weak euro. That’s why Lekas likes German companies. Two favorites are Deutsche Telekom DTEGY, +1.61% and Allianz AZSEY, +0.71% an insurer, in part because they pay decent dividends of 3.8% and 4.4%. Deakins, at RidgeWorth International Equity Fund, likes Paris-based Cap Gemini CGEMY, +0.22% which offers information-technology consulting in Europe and abroad. He also likes Ambev ABEV, +2.25% which makes Budweiser beer, for its brand strength and exposure to emerging markets. Both companies are plays on a continuing rebound in the global economy, not just better European growth. “We are only halfway into this economic cycle, and it will have a number of years of positive growth before things get negative again,” Deakins says. “We will see growth until central banks stop raising rates and they have not even started yet.” If you buy European stocks, expect volatility as problems like the conflict in Ukraine and Greek debt issues flare up. But if you are a real long-term investor like Warren Buffett, you should welcome volatility as Buffett does, since it gives you a chance to add to positions at lower prices. At the time of publication, Michael Brush had no positions in any stocks mentioned in this column. Brush is a Manhattan-based financial writer who publishes the stock newsletter Brush Up on Stocks. Brush has covered business for the New York Times and The Economist group, and he attended Columbia Business School in the Knight-Bagehot program. content: SÃO PAULO-- Companhia de Bebidas das Americas, or AmBev, on Friday said its profit increased in its third quarter, as lower debt service costs helped offset tepid sales. The brewer of such beer brands as Skol and Brahma posted a third-quarter net profit of 2.89 billion reais ($1.2 billion), up from BRL2.35 billion in the same period last year. "After a solid first half of the year, we experienced a softer third quarter as a result of a weaker macroeconomic environment in Brazil and poor weather in Canada," the company said in a statement. The company's revenue increased 0.9% to BRL8.17 billion in the quarter. Meanwhile, AmBev debt service costs totaled BRL221 million in the period, compared with BRL497.4 million a year ago. AmBev said its earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization totaled BRL4.09 billion in the third quarter, down from BRL4.22 billion a year ago. content: SÃO PAULO-- Companhia de Bebidas das Americas, or AmBev, on Thursday reported an increase in its net profit in the second quarter, as its sales were fueled by the World Cup in June. The brewer of such beer brands as Skol and Brahma posted a second-quarter net profit of 2.22 billion reais ($988.7 million), up from 1.9 billion reais ($846.2 million) in the year-ago period. "During 32 days, we experienced a huge event in Brazil with soccer fans celebrating with their loved beer brands in their homes, bars, stadiums and thousands of events organized around the country," the company said in a statement. It said June 11 was "the best-selling day in our history, " with more than 400,000 hectoliters (10.6 million gallons) of beer sold in Brazil. The World Cup took place in Brazil from June 12 to July 13. The company's revenue increased 9.2% to 8.17 billion reais in the second quarter. Commercial expenses totaled 2.34 billion reais in the period, up from 2.1 billion reais a year earlier. AmBev reported that earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization totaled 3.32 billion reais in the second quarter, up from 3.23 billion reais in the second quarter of 2013. content: S�O PAULO,  July 27, 2017 /PRNewswire/ – Ambev S.A. [BOVESPA: ABEV3; NYSE: ABEV] announces today its results for the 2017 second quarter. The following operating and financial information, unless otherwise indicated, is presented in nominal Reais and prepared according to International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), and should be read together with our quarterly financial information for the six-month period ended June 30 [th] , 2017 filed with the CVM and submitted to the SEC. Operating and Financial Highlights Top line performance: Top line was up 4.8% in 2Q17, driven by growth in all our international operations: Latin America South (LAS) (+36.2%), Central America and the Caribbean (CAC) (+6.9%) and Canada (+1.4%), partially impacted by Brazil (-4.1%). In Brazil, volumes declined by 4.7%, while NR/hl was up 0.7%. In CAC, organic volumes were up 1.6%, with a NR/hl growth of 4.2%, while reported volumes increased by 26.2% as a result of the swap of assets carried out with ABI and our operations in Panama. In LAS, volumes grew by a solid 12.2% and NR/hl was up 21.4%. In Canada, volumes were slightly down (-0.4%), while NR/hl grew by 1.8%. Cost of Goods Sold (COGS): Our COGS increased by 10.6% in the quarter and, on a per hectoliter basis, by 11.6%. Cash COGS (excluding depreciation and amortization) grew by 11.2% while, on a per hectoliter basis, by 12.2%, mainly due to inflationary pressures and unfavorable FX in Brazil and LAS. Selling, General & Administrative (SG&A) expenses: SG&A was up 1.3% in 2Q17 while cash SG&A (excluding depreciation and amortization) up 1.7%, below our weighted average inflation (around 5.1%), due to efficiency gains in sales & marketing and cost savings in administrative expenses. EBITDA, Gross margin and EBITDA margin: Normalized EBITDA reached R$ 3,943.3 million (-0.7%) in 2Q17, with gross margin of 60.6% (-200bps) and EBITDA margin of 38.4% (-210bps). Normalized Net Profit and EPS: Normalized Net Profit was R$ 2,141.5 million in 2Q17, 2.4% lower than in 2Q16, as the EBITDA organic decline and the negative impact of currency translation due to the appreciation of the Brazilian Real were partially offset by the reduction of net financial expenses. Normalized EPS in the quarter was R$ 0.13. Cash Generation and CAPEX: Cash generated from operating activities in 2Q17 was 2,424.6 (+16.5%) while CAPEX reached 751 million (-34.8%). Year to date, cash generated from operating activities totaled R$ 4,409.1 million, compared to a negative balance of R$ 132.9 million in the same period of 2016. CAPEX year to date is R$ 1.3 billion (-29.5%).  Pay-out and Financial discipline: Year to date, we have paid/announced R$ 3.6 billion in dividends. As of June 30th, 2017, our net cash position was R$ 3,821.4 million. content: S�O PAULO, May 4, 2017 /PRNewswire/ -- Ambev S.A. [BOVESPA: ABEV3; NYSE: ABEV] announces today its results for the 2017 first quarter (1Q17). The following operating and financial information, unless otherwise indicated, is presented in nominal Reais and prepared according to International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), and should be read together with our quarterly financial information for the three-month period ended March 31 [st] , 2017 filed with the CVM and submitted to the SEC. Operating and Financial Highlights Top line performance: Top line was up 8.0% in the quarter, driven by growth in all operations: Brazil (+0.6%), Latin America South (LAS) (+27.4%), Central America and the Caribbean (CAC) (+5.5%) and Canada (+2.3%). Consolidated volumes were up 2.4%, growing in most regions, and net revenue per hectoliter (NR/hl) increased by 5.3%. In Brazil, volumes grew by 2.6%, while NR/hl was down 1.9%. In CAC, while organic volumes were up 1.2% with a NR/hl growth of 3.4%, reported volumes increased by 27.3%, as a result of the swap of assets carried out with ABI and our operations in Panama. In LAS, volumes increased by 3.1% and NR/hl was up 23.3%, reflecting the high inflation in the region. In Canada, volumes were slightly down (-0.9%), with a solid 3.3% NR/hl growth.  Cost of Goods Sold (COGS): Our COGS increased by 26.4% in 1Q17 while, on a per hectoliter basis, it grew by 23.1%, mainly due to inflationary pressures and unfavorable currency in Brazil and LAS. Selling, General & Administrative (SG&A) expenses: SG&A (excluding depreciation and amortization) in 1Q17 was up 6.4%, with efficiency gains in non working money and cost savings in working money. EBITDA, Gross margin and EBITDA margin: Normalized EBITDA reached R$ 4,356 million (-7.6%) in 1Q17 with gross margin of 59.8% (-580bps) and EBITDA margin of 38.7% (-670bps). Normalized Net Profit and EPS: Normalized Net Profit was R$ 2,316 million in 1Q17, 20.1% below 1Q16, driven mainly by a lower EBITDA and currency translation due to the appreciation of the Brazilian Real. Normalized EPS in the quarter was R$ 0.14. Operating Cash Generation and CAPEX: Cash generated from operations in 1Q17 was R$ 3.1 billionversusR$ 2.3 billion in 1Q16 (+37.7%). In the quarter, CAPEX reached R$ 559 million, 20.9% lower than in 1Q16. Other cash gains: We have recorded in our Equity a cash gain of R$ 159 million, related to the recovery of restricted funds, to be received in 36 installments as of January, 2017. Pay-out and Financial discipline: In 1Q17, we returned approximately R$ 1.1 billion to equity holders in dividends. As of March 31 [st] , 2017, our net cash position was R$ 2,106 million.
